contentrichtext.text: {{other uses}} {{Refimprove|date=October 2009}} The '''phon''' is a [[physical unit|unit]] of [[loudness]] level for pure tones. Its purpose is to compensate for the effect of frequency on the perceived loudness of tones.<ref>William M. Hartmann, ''Signals, Sound, and Sensation'', American Institute of Physics, 2004. ISBN 1-56396-283-7.</ref> The phon was proposed in DIN 45631 and ISO 532 B by [[Stanley Smith Stevens|S. S. Stevens]].<ref>[http://www.phys.unsw.edu.au/~jw/dB.html#log UNSW Music Acoustics<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> ==Definition== By definition, 1 phon is equal to 1 [[sound pressure level|dBSPL]] at a frequency of 1 [[kHz]].<ref>Nave, C. R. (2002-02-10). Loudness Units: Phons and Sones. HyperPhysics. Retrieved on 2008-07-10 from http://hyperphysics.phy-astr.gsu.edu/hbase/sound/phon.html.</ref> The [[equal-loudness contour]]s are a way of mapping the dBSPL of a pure tone to the perceived loudness level (''L''<sub>N</sub>) in phons. These are now defined in the international standard ISO 226:2003, and the research on which this document is based concluded that earlier [[Fletcherâ€“Munson curves]] and [[Robinson-Dadson curves]] were in error.{{Citation needed|date=October 2009}} The phon unit is not an SI unit in [[metrology]]. It has not been accepted as a standard unit by the United States [[National Institute of Standards and Technology]].{{Citation needed|date=October 2009}} The phon model can be extended with a time-varying transient model which accounts for "turn-on" (initial transient) and long-term, [[listener fatigue]] effects. This time-varying behavior is the result of [[psychology|psychological]] and [[physiology|physiological]] audio processing. The equal-loudness contours on which the phon is based apply only to the perception of pure steady tones: tests using octave or third-octave bands of noise reveal a different set of curves, owing to the way in which the [[critical band]]s of our hearing integrate power over varying bandwidths and our brain sums the various critical bands.{{Clarify|date=October 2009}}{{Citation needed|date=October 2009}} ==See also== *[[Sone]] *[[A-weighting]] *[[Decibel]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://ccrma.stanford.edu/~jos/TimeFreqDisplay/Sones_Phons.html Explanation with definitions] *[http://www.sengpielaudio.com/calculatorSonephon.htm Conversion: loudness level ''L'' (phons) to Loudness ''N'' and vice versa] [[Category:Hearing]] [[Category:Human-based units of measurement]] [[Category:Units of sound]]
